title: SB 1053
content:
The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 12927 of the Government Code is amended to define "Affirmative actions" as activities to eliminate discrimination in housing accommodations based on various factors. "Conciliation council" refers to organizations providing services for resolving complaints of housing discrimination. "Discrimination in housing includes refusal to sell, rent, or lease accommodations, denial of housing, provision of inferior terms, harassment, cancellation of agreements, segregation, and refusal to permit reasonable modifications for disabled persons." The landlord may condition permission for modifications on the renter agreeing to restore the premises to its original condition. Refusal to make reasonable accommodations for disabled persons is considered discrimination in housing. (2) "Discrimination" excludes refusal to rent a portion of an owner-occupied single-family house to a roomer or boarder living within the household, as long as only one person is living there. It also includes the use of words implying housing is only for one sex in shared living areas. "Housing accommodation" refers to any building or structure intended for residence by one or more families. (e) “Owner” includes lessee, sublessee, assignee, managing agent, real estate broker, or any person with legal or equitable ownership or possession rights. It also includes the state, political subdivisions, and agencies.
(f) “Person” includes individuals, entities described in Section 3602(d) of Title 42 of the United States Code, and institutional third parties.
(g) “Aggrieved person” refers to anyone claiming injury from discriminatory housing practices.
(h) “Real estate-related transactions” encompass various transactions related to real estate. (i) "Real estate-related transactions" involve activities such as making loans for dwelling purchases, selling residential property, and imposing territorial underwriting requirements for earthquake insurance. 
(ii) "Source of income" refers to verifiable income directly paid to a tenant or their representative, excluding landlords. The curr_chunk discusses housing discrimination laws, prohibiting discrimination based on various factors including race, religion, gender, and source of income. It also mentions federal housing assistance vouchers under Section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937. The curr_chunk prohibits inquiries or advertisements that discriminate based on various factors when selling or renting housing accommodations. The curr_chunk prohibits discrimination in housing accommodations based on various factors such as sex, gender, sexual orientation, race, religion, and more. The curr_chunk prohibits discrimination in financial assistance for housing based on various factors such as race, religion, gender, sexual orientation, and more. The curr_chunk prohibits retaliation against individuals opposing unlawful housing practices or assisting in legal proceedings. It also prohibits aiding, abetting, or coercing such discriminatory acts. The curr_chunk prohibits discrimination in housing based on various protected characteristics such as race, color, religion, gender, sexual orientation, marital status, disability, and national origin. The curr_chunk prohibits discrimination in housing based on various protected characteristics such as race, color, religion, gender, sexual orientation, marital status, disability, and national origin, including denying access or membership based on these factors. The curr_chunk prohibits discrimination in housing based on various protected characteristics, including race, color, religion, gender, sexual orientation, marital status, disability, and national origin. Discrimination includes actions such as restrictive covenants and denials of use permits that make housing opportunities unavailable. The curr_chunk expands on the prohibited discrimination in housing by including characteristics such as gender identity, familial status, and source of income. It also addresses using financial standards that do not account for aggregate income or government rent subsidies when assessing eligibility for housing. The curr_chunk defines "source of income" for housing purposes and clarifies that inquiring about income level is not discrimination. It also mentions potential reimbursement for costs mandated by the state.
